text:
so here's our chicken nicely rested you 
want to always rest your chicken even if

you had rice already normally you'd spend this 
time cooking the rice while the chicken cools

but you want to make sure the chicken is cool 
before you cut it or juices will run and also

you'll burn your hand so I'm gonna show you how 
I take apart this chicken I'm gonna take off the

breast first but in order to do that see how 
he's not sitting very well I'm gonna open up

the leg just by cutting that skin there that's 
holding it together and just open it so he's a

little more stable there and now he will sit 
there for me you want to run your knife right

up against the keel bone which is right in the 
middle separating the breasts oh I went on the

wrong side and then you're just gonna run your 
knife against the ribcage so you always want

to be feeling the ribcage because that's how 
you know you're taking off as much meat as is

possible and then when you get to the end slice 
that off slice off the part that's connected to

the wing there and then you've got one nice 
breast put that there turn it be if you're

right-handed like me turn the chicken the other 
way so then the breast falls into your hand and

then Asia you see them taking 
a big cleaver and whack whack

whack everything into seconds but don't 
need to be aggressive about this okay

okay there's two breaths and now we're gonna 
take off the thigh see this by joint I'm gonna

turn it so you can now see the joint that popped 
up because you and you know exactly where to cut

and then you don't need to exert any effort you 
just cut around the joint and then he comes up

nicely same thing on the other side pop it so 
the joint is exposed like that and then you

just cut without needing to exert any force 
okay then you want to look for the oyster if

you want moister is the delicious meat usually 
stuck in this part here I try to get it all in

one piece but that doesn't usually happen it's 
like the most delicious piece of the chicken

thigh so now the wings just take off the wings 
if you cut between joints you should not have

to exert any force whatsoever if you having to 
exert force that means you're trying to cut in

between bones and that's not necessary so you can 
save this for a diluted stock if you'd like so I

want to note that if you cook your chicken to 
165 degrees and then around the bones of your

thighs and your drumsticks there's redness like 
a little sort of what looks like bloodiness here

that is normal it is fine to eat its bacteria 
that gets you sick not blood and at 165 all

the disease-causing bacteria are dead but the 
blood cooks at a higher temperature so if you

want to cook the blood so that it doesn't look 
any bloody bloody any more you'll have to cook

your chicken further which is going to render 
your chicken a little overcooked but if that

makes you feel better you can go ahead and 
do that I just want to let you know that if

you've test a temperature and it's at 165 
you still see blood it's absolutely fine
